title: Reading some of these ban posts I'm becoming scared.
body:
I've seen a few posts now that are starting to scare me because they all have one thing in common, they apparently get flagged for "scripting" but the only 3rd party program they mention is some type of recording or replay software that in no way interferes with the game. Another thing the reports have in common is Riot support refuses to elaborate on the ban and basically just say "system said ur scripting ur not getting unbanned skriptlord420" I understand that you cannot describe how the system detected it or whatever along those lines, What I don't understand is when someone has a legitimate dispute against that ban and has ways to prove there was no cheating involved, they're given a cold shoulder by riot support. one in particular was a very recent post by a challenger player on LAN who was banned for 3rd party programs and when he contacted riot they bluntly said the system detected him as scripting and they said nothing further.

This bothers me the most because I'm currently using Overwolf in game which I have shamelessly advertised with the link. The specific feature I use is their instant replay system which allows you to watch a replay of the last 20 seconds in game so you can possibly see what you did wrong or just so you can watch a sick play again. I've seen numerous reports by people permabanned for supposedly scripting when in reality they're just using a replay or recording system. 

Overwolf and other replay systems in no way interfere with the game or give you an unfair advantage. Yes they are 3rd party programs but if rewatching the game so you can improve and not make the same mistakes again is against the rules then you can go ahead and ban 70% of the community that record their games or have replay systems.

Personally I feel Riot needs to just remove all automated systems that can result in such harsh punishment, These systems seem to misjudge a lot of people and flag them as cheating when in reality they are doing nothing at all wrong, then when it flags them and they are banned Riot support and most Rioters in general give them a cold shoulder without actually investigating and admitting that the ban was wrong.
I've been saying a huge trend lately of Riot never wanted to reverse something that needs to be reversed, maybe it's  from an inflated ego and thinking everything they do is perfect. I'm not quite sure why it's happening but I've seen too many examples of not fixing something that wasn't right.

Either directly say "Riot as a company feels that a replay system can somehow give you an unfair advantage against the competing team so it will result in a permanent ban" or stop punishing people for it.

They have the TOS the way it currently is for good reason. I can think of several just off the top of my head:
1) In order to protect their copyright to the code, they can't (in a legal document) give people permission to modify it
2) If they say something like "Custom skin programs are always okay" in the TOS, someone will find a way to exploit it by making skins where hitboxes are clearly visible or something
3) "offer no advantages to the player" is subjective and mutable, and won't hold up in court. If the TOS can't hold up in court, RIOT is making a major, stupid business mistake.

They made the right choice by leaving the rules as they are and selectively enforcing it, rather than trying to write mutable rules that can't hold up in a legal document

To be fair, no TOS holds any legal weight of any kind. The only part of the agreement between you and Riot Games that actually matters is the part where you hold no rights whatsoever to the account you created and the content you unlocked.

If we look at [Violating website TOS is not a crime (via eff.com)](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2010/07/court-violating-terms-service-not-crime-bypassing) we see an example specifically targeting a website TOS from 2010, but the idea remains the same. A corporation whether for a digital product or website doesn't write the law. A TOS agreement at best can be cited to remove an end-user's access to the service. Any other scenario that could be covered in a TOS clause is already handled by real case law, e.g. Cyber-fraud, unauthorized access of a computer system, etc.
